Package com.roscopeco.moxy.api

Interface MoxyEngine


  • public interface MoxyEngine

    A MoxyEngine is the class that is responsible for generating mocks according to whatever strategy it is designed to use.

    It usually also coordinates activities of mocks, as well as integrating the matchers.

    The default implementation uses the ASM library to generate mocks at runtime. If you wish to replace that implementation, see Moxy.setMoxyEngine(MoxyEngine).

    Since:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ross Bamford <roscopeco AT gmail DOT com>

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        void reset​()

        Reset this engine.

        Implementations may choose to globally reset the mocking framework, or to reset only for the current thread. This must be documented with the engine implementation.

        The default engine reset()s on a per-thread basis.

        Since:
        1.0

      • getMockClass

        <I> Class<? extends I> getMockClass​(ClassLoader loader,
                                    Class<I> clz,
                                    Set<Method> methods,
                                    PrintStream trace)

        Create a mock class of the given class and then define it in the given ClassLoader.

        This method allows only a specific subset of methods to be mocked. Please note, however, that any abstract methods will always be mocked in order to generate loadable classes. This also applies to interfaces, in which all methods (except those with a default implementation) are considered abstract.

        The MoxyEngine class provides two useful constants you may want to use for the methods parameter:

        
   MoxyEngine.ALL_METHODS       // mock all methods
   MoxyEngine.NO_METHODS        // mock no methods

        Generated Mock classes will define public pass-through constructors to all public constructors on the superclass (if concrete), or a single public constructor (if mocking an interface). These constructors will have the same arguments as the original constructor, with a single argument of type MoxyEngine prepended.

        Therefore, to instantiate a mock from a class, you will need to obtain the appropriate constructor via reflection and call it, passing in the MoxyEngine that created the mock followed by any other arguments the constructor requires.

        These constructors are generated primarily for use with partial mocking. If you are mocking the entire class (i.e. all methods) you may prefer to use mock(Class) and friends instead.

        During creation of the mock, this method will also dump the generated bytecode, in a debugging format, to the supplied PrintStream.

        Type Parameters:
        I - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        loader - The ClassLoader to define the new class in.
        clz - The original class.
        methods - Set of Methods to mock.
        trace - If non-null, the resulting class will be dumped (with a TraceClassVisitor) to the given stream.
        Returns:
        The new Class object.
        Since:
        1.0

      • getMockClass

        <I> Class<? extends I> getMockClass​(ClassLoader loader,
                                    Class<I> clz,
                                    Set<Method> methods)

        Create a mock class of the given class and then define it in the given ClassLoader.

        This method allows only a specific subset of methods to be mocked. Please note, however, that any abstract methods will always be mocked in order to generate loadable classes. This also applies to interfaces, in which all methods (except those with a default implementation) are considered abstract.

        The MoxyEngine class provides two useful constants you may want to use for the methods parameter:

   MoxyEngine.NO_METHODS        // mock no methods

        Generated Mock classes will define public pass-through constructors to all public constructors on the superclass (if concrete), or a single public constructor (if mocking an interface). These constructors will have the same arguments as the original constructor, with a single argument of type MoxyEngine prepended.

        Therefore, to instantiate a mock from a class, you will need to obtain the appropriate constructor via reflection and call it, passing in the MoxyEngine that created the mock followed by any other arguments the constructor requires.

        These constructors are generated primarily for use with partial mocking. If you are mocking the entire class (i.e. all methods) you may prefer to use mock(Class) and friends instead.

        Type Parameters:
        I - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        loader - The ClassLoader to define the new class in.
        clz - The original class.
        methods - Set of Methods to mock.
        Returns:
        The new Class object.

        See Also:

      • getMockClass

        <I> Class<? extends I> getMockClass​(Class<I> clz,
                                    Set<Method> methods)

        Create a mock class of the given class and then define it in the engine's default ClassLoader.

        For the default engine, the default ClassLoader is the same ClassLoader that loaded the Moxy framework.

        This method allows only a specific subset of methods to be mocked. Please note, however, that any abstract methods will always be mocked in order to generate loadable classes. This also applies to interfaces, in which all methods (except those with a default implementation) are considered abstract.

        The MoxyEngine class provides two useful constants you may want to use for the methods parameter:

        
   MoxyEngine.ALL_METHODS       // mock all methods
   MoxyEngine.NO_METHODS        // mock no methods

        Generated Mock classes will define public pass-through constructors to all public constructors on the superclass (if concrete), or a single public constructor (if mocking an interface). These constructors will have the same arguments as the original constructor, with a single argument of type MoxyEngine prepended.

        Therefore, to instantiate a mock from a class, you will need to obtain the appropriate constructor via reflection and call it, passing in the MoxyEngine that created the mock followed by any other arguments the constructor requires.

        These constructors are generated primarily for use with partial mocking. If you are mocking the entire class (i.e. all methods) you may prefer to use mock(Class) and friends instead.

        Type Parameters:
        I - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        clz - The original class.
        methods - Set of Methods to mock.
        Returns:
        The new Class object.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getMockClass(ClassLoader, Class, Set)

      • getMockClass

        <I> Class<? extends I> getMockClass​(Class<I> clz,
                                    PrintStream trace)

        Create a mock class of the given class and then define it in the engine's default ClassLoader.

        For the default engine, the default ClassLoader is the same ClassLoader that loaded the Moxy framework.

        Generated Mock classes will define public pass-through constructors to all public constructors on the superclass (if concrete), or a single public constructor (if mocking an interface). These constructors will have the same arguments as the original constructor, with a single argument of type MoxyEngine prepended.

        Therefore, to instantiate a mock from a class, you will need to obtain the appropriate constructor via reflection and call it, passing in the MoxyEngine that created the mock followed by any other arguments the constructor requires.

        These constructors are generated primarily for use with partial mocking. If you are mocking the entire class (i.e. all methods) you may prefer to use mock(Class) and friends instead.

        During creation of the mock, this method will also dump the generated bytecode, in a debugging format, to the supplied PrintStream.

        Type Parameters:
        I - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        clz - The original class.
        trace - If non-null, the resulting class will be dumped (with a TraceClassVisitor) to the given stream.
        Returns:
        The new Class object.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getMockClass(ClassLoader, Class, Set, PrintStream)

      • getMockClass

        <I> Class<? extends I> getMockClass​(Class<I> clz,
                                    Set<Method> methods,
                                    PrintStream trace)

        Create a mock class of the given class and then define it in the engine's default ClassLoader.

        For the default engine, the default ClassLoader is the same ClassLoader that loaded the Moxy framework.

        This method allows only a specific subset of methods to be mocked. Please note, however, that any abstract methods will always be mocked in order to generate loadable classes. This also applies to interfaces, in which all methods (except those with a default implementation) are considered abstract.

        The MoxyEngine class provides two useful constants you may want to use for the methods parameter:

        
   MoxyEngine.ALL_METHODS       // mock all methods
   MoxyEngine.NO_METHODS        // mock no methods

        Generated Mock classes will define public pass-through constructors to all public constructors on the superclass (if concrete), or a single public constructor (if mocking an interface). These constructors will have the same arguments as the original constructor, with a single argument of type MoxyEngine prepended.

        Therefore, to instantiate a mock from a class, you will need to obtain the appropriate constructor via reflection and call it, passing in the MoxyEngine that created the mock followed by any other arguments the constructor requires.

        These constructors are generated primarily for use with partial mocking. If you are mocking the entire class (i.e. all methods) you may prefer to use mock(Class) and friends instead.

        During creation of the mock, this method will also dump the generated bytecode, in a debugging format, to the supplied PrintStream.

        Type Parameters:
        I - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        clz - The original class.
        methods - Set of Methods to mock.
        trace - If non-null, the resulting class will be dumped (with a TraceClassVisitor) to the given stream.
        Returns:
        The new Class object.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        getMockClass(ClassLoader, Class, Set, PrintStream)

      • mock

        <T> T mock​(Class<T> clz)

        Create a mock instance of the given class.

        The mock will be created in the engine's default ClassLoader. For the default engine, this is the same ClassLoader that loaded the engine.

        Note: This method will not call a constructor on the generated instance. If you require a constructor be called, please see getMockClass(Class) and friends.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type being mocked.
        Parameters:
        clz - The Class to mock.
        Returns:
        A new mock instance.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        mock(Class, PrintStream)

        Note: This method will not call a constructor on the generated instance. If you require a constructor be called, please see getMockClass(Class) and friends.

      • isMock

        boolean isMock​(Class<?> clz)

        Determines whether the supplied class is a mock class.

        How this determination is made is implementation-dependent, but may rely on the fact that the class has the (mandatory) MoxyMock annotation.

        Parameters:
        clz - The class to query.
        Returns:
        true if the class is a mock, false otherwise.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isMock(Object)

      • isMock

        boolean isMock​(Object obj)

        Determines whether the supplied object is a mock instance.

        How this determination is made is implementation-dependent, but may rely on the fact that the class has the (mandatory) MoxyMock annotation.

        Parameters:
        obj - The object to query.
        Returns:
        true if the class is a mock, false otherwise.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        isMock(Class)

      • resetMock

        void resetMock​(Object mock)

        Reset the supplied mock, removing all stubbing that was previously applied.

        Note that this does not operate on a thread-local basis, (since stubbing is not thread-local) and that it does not reset previous invocation data for the mock. If you wish to reset that, see reset().

        Parameters:
        mock - The mock to reset
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        reset()

      • when

        <T> MoxyStubber<T> when​(InvocationSupplier<T> invocation)

        Starts stubbing of the mock invocation in the supplied lambda expression.

        The invocation of the mock is used to determine which method and argument combination is to be stubbed and is not counted toward mock invocation, return or throw counters.

        Example usage:

        
 engine.when(() -> mock.someMethod("one", "two")).thenReturn("three");

        The arguments passed to the mock within the lambda may be either immediate arguments, other mocks, or argument matchers (see Matchers).

        This method begins a new chain of stubbing for the given invocation - Any prior stubbing applied is discarded, to be replaced by the stubbing applied on the returned MoxyStubber.

        See MoxyStubber for details on the stubbing methods available.

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type being stubbed (the return type of the mocked method).
        Parameters:
        invocation - A lambda that will invoke the method to be stubbed.
        Returns:
        A MoxyStubber that will stub the given method.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        when(InvocationRunnable), MoxyStubber

      • when

        MoxyVoidStubber when​(InvocationRunnable invocation)

        Starts stubbing of the mock invocation in the supplied lambda expression.

        The Java compiler will automatically select this overload of the when method when the method to be stubbed is void.

        The invocation of the mock is used to determine which method and argument combination is to be stubbed and is not counted toward mock invocation, return or throw counters.

        Example usage:

        
 engine.when(() -> mock.voidMethod("one", "two")).thenThrow("three");

        The arguments passed to the mock within the lambda may be either immediate arguments, other mocks, or argument matchers (see Matchers).

        This method begins a new chain of stubbing for the given invocation - Any prior stubbing applied is discarded, to be replaced by the stubbing applied on the returned MoxyVoidStubber.

        See MoxyStubber for details on the stubbing methods available.

        Parameters:
        invocation - A lambda that will invoke the method to be stubbed.
        Returns:
        A MoxyVoidStubber that will stub the given method.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        when(InvocationSupplier), MoxyStubber

      • assertMock

        MoxyVerifier assertMock​(InvocationRunnable invocation)

        Starts verification of the mock invocation in the supplied lambda expression.

        The invocation of the mock is used to determine which method and argument combination is to be verified and is not counted toward mock invocation, return or throw counters.

        Example usage:

        
 engine.assertMock(() -> mock.voidMethod(engine, "one", "two")).wasCalled();

        The arguments passed to the mock within the lambda may be either immediate arguments, other mocks, or argument matchers (see Matchers).

        See MoxyVerifier for details on the verifying methods available.

        Parameters:
        invocation - A lambda that will invoke the method to be stubbed.
        Returns:
        A MoxyVerifier that will verify the given method.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        MoxyVerifier

      • assertMocks

        MoxyMultiVerifier assertMocks​(InvocationRunnable invocation)

        Starts verification of one or more mock invocations at the same time. This allows multiple invocations to be checked together to ensure ordering, for example.

        The invocation of the mock is used to determine which method and argument combination is to be verified and is not counted toward mock invocation, return or throw counters.

        Example usage:

        
 engine.assertMocks(() -> {
   mock.voidMethod(engine, "one", "two")).wasCalled();
   mock.anotherMethod();

   anotherMock.someMethod("five");

   mock.finalMethod("Bees");
 })
     .wereAllCalledOnce()
     .inThatOrder();

        The arguments passed to the mocks within the lambda may be either immediate arguments, other mocks, or argument matchers (see Matchers).

        See MoxyMultiVerifier for details on the verifying methods available.

        Parameters:
        invocation - A lambda that will invoke the methods to be verified.
        Returns:
        A MoxyMultiVerifier that will verify the invocations.
        Since:
        1.0
        See Also:
        assertMock(InvocationRunnable)

      • registerMatcher

        void registerMatcher​(MoxyMatcher<?> matcher)

        Register the given matcher with this MoxyEngine.

        This method triggers a two-step process, whereby the engine takes care of any housekeeping required and then calls back to the MoxyMatcher.addToStack(java.util.Deque) method, passing in the appropriate stack.

        See the documentation on MoxyMatcher for more information.

        Parameters:
        matcher - The MoxyMatcher to register.
        Since:
        1.0
